reviewText: As tight as they are on CD,  "America's Favorite Instrumental Combo" is better to watch on DVD.  Choreographic,  robotic moves in duos, threesomes and all four members come out  entertaining.  Introductions in Spanish are comical.  Los Straightjackets always wearing wrestling masks turns a concert into their own circus. There are  minimal camera audience shots because the group is the show.  Oh about the music.  The guys  play  sort of a  "Greatest Hits Live" set list mixing tempos, keys and a variety of beats pacing all the songs so boredom never comes close - "Itchy Chicken".  Los Straightjackets has a well respected reputation for thundering explosiveness - "Rockula".  I found their true craftsmanship of how good they can really play their instruments on the slow songs - "My Heart Will Go On" (Love Theme From Titanic).  The ending which I don't want to ruin,  playing  the old classic "Telstar" caps everything off visually in climatic fashion.  No trick cameras, props,  gimmicks or illusions...hint...hint?  70 minutes is just right for this type of act.  As Ed Sullivan used to say "We Have A Really Good Show"......An AMAZON.COM WISH FOR CUSTOMERS:  A DVD exists of the detailed history of surf music and late 50s, early 60s instrumentals hosted by Paul Johnson of The Belairs titled "Pounding Surf"! It also has modern day live performances from legends from the past.  I hope AMAZON adds this to the website for those curious about the Surf Music sub-culture.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have seen Los Straitjackets live on two occasions both times with the legendary and classic guitar instrumental group The Ventures.  This DVD is an excellent potrayal of a Los Straitjacket's concert.  The video quality and sound are both excellent.  The song selection is nearly identical to the CD Damas y Caballeros! Recorded several years ago in Long Beach, CA. this concert was taken for two venues both in the San Francisco Bay area.  One song I wish they would have included is Batman theme.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First of all, I have to agree with reviewer D. Beyer. Whichever company actually manufactured this DVD (Yep Roc Records or whomever) needs to get a grip on quality control. When I put my copy of this DVD on my player, it kept loading for 30-60 seconds and then, the dreaded "bad disc" logo appeared! After my blood pressure spiked and I calmed down a bit, I placed the disc on my DVD RECORDER and it played! Because of the way my system is set up, I was unable to enjoy the 5.1 Surround Sound, but that's another story. After I played the disc all the way through, I placed it on my DVD player and, this time, it worked perfectly!Anyway, enough of the problems the manufacturer has and the customer must work around (Amazon take note).I have been a fan of Los Straitjackets for almost 10 years and have seen them live in concert twice. I would have seen them more, but they don't come to the East Coast that often. The DVD depicts a "typical" live concert wherein the audience is not seated, but is standing around the bandstand. Why? It's very curious. One would think that the audience would be dancing, but what they're doing is actually WATCHING a performance! They're completely entranced with what's going on in front of them and don't want to miss a single second. I've seen this in person, so I'm assuming this happens all the time with these guys.To try to explain what Los Straitjackets does is difficult, if not impossible. If you hear them, then see them, you'll get it. They are four musicians who are so good at what they do, they have fun with their music and let the listeners/audience in on "the joke". By good, I should say great. Danny Amis and Eddie Angel trade off on taking lead guitar, Pete Curry plays a steady bass, similar to the late John Entwistle of The Who (but can hold up on lead with Amis and Angel), and Jimmy Lester "maybe" plays drums. I say "maybe" because he has a mask on and I'm not so sure that this isn't the ghost of Buddy Rich or Gene Krupa playing, especially on "Swing, Swing, Swing".Twenty bucks is a bit steep for non-Blu-Ray DVDs now-a-days, so you'd better be getting your hard earned money's worth. In my opinion, you do with this DVD (aside for the "bad disc" logo thing). Once it started playing right and I could hear the 5.1 mix, it was just like being at one of their live concerts without the waitress coming over and checking on the amount of beer you had left in the bottle.Los Straitjackets are not everyones cup of tea. However, if you remember what powerhouse surf music or the guitar shreading of Link Wray or the tightness of The Ventures AND the humor of Spike Jones sounded and looked like, check out Los Straitjackets and find a machine that will allow you to play the DVD. I repeat, IT'S ABOUT TIME Los Straitjackets put out an authorized DVD. Thank you, Misters Angel, Curry, Amis, and Lester.

reviewText: This DVD captures the masked surf instrumentalists known as Los Straitjackets, in a 65 minute live performance recorded in 2005 at the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco (for the most part).  Released in 2008, the concert features music up to their 2003 release, Supersonic Guitars in 3-D.  The performance has an amusing lead in clip, featuring the band surfing at the beach, and then madly racing to make the show.  The lineup for this concert consists of Danny Amis (guitar), Eddie Angel (guitar), Pete Curry (bass) and Jimmy Lester (drums), dressed in their customary stage attire, dark shirts and jeans, wrestling masks, sneakers, and Aztec medallions, with Amis, Angel, and Curry playing glittered up DiPinto Galaxie guitars and bass.The intimate venue may not have been the ideal choice to shoot a concert video.  The band is obstructed by the audience in wide shots, because the crowd is up at the foot of the rather low stage.  There are cameras down in the front that do provide unobstructed views, although the viewing angle is a bit low.  There are also other cameras providing additional coverage as well.  The lighting on the band is pretty sedate, and rather static.  The performance could have benefited from a little more dynamic lighting.  Low light levels result in less than the best video quality at times.From a musical performance standpoint, the band is in fine form, performing like a finely tuned machine.  Guitarists Angel and Amis, typically alternate playing lead on the instrumentals.  The stage is rather small and with the drum kit is setup just a few feet back from the front, there isn't a lot of room to move around, just enough space for the group's mildly entertaining choreographed maneuvers, such as on Time Bomb and Casbah.  Between every two or three numbers, there is a short verbal outburst, always by Amis (Daddy-O), which is mostly in Spanish, with the occasional song or album title in English sprinkled in.  And then the band is off again.And so it goes for 21 songs in all.  As the music is all instrumentals, the focus is usually on the lead guitar player of the moment, with adequate coverage still given to the other players.  If you are a guitar player, you will be able to see how a lot of the songs are played (check out Itchy Chicken).  Amis and Angel apparently do not use specially tweaked guitars for particular songs, and appear to do the entire show without swapping out their instruments.  The songs are executed flawlessly, and the audience appears to be having a great time.  Among the many highlights are Tailspin, Rockula, Squad Car, Calhoun Surf, Sing Sing Sing, Kawanga, Tempest, Itchy Chicken, and the classic Out of Limits.The 120 minute run time stated in Amazon's description is incorrect.  The complete video actually runs about 71 minutes.  Available audio options are stereo and Dolby 5.1.  There are no extras, which is disappointing, since the performance is a few years old, and there was ample time to prepare something.  Drummer Jimmy Lester left the band in 2005, shortly after this was recorded.  Guitar players interested in the Straitjacket's sound may want to take a look at the DiPinto Galaxie 4, and the Los Straitjackets model, which looks exactly like the guitars the guys are playing.Although a venue more suited for filming might have produced more attractive results, this is still a fine representation of the band, and highly recommended to their fans, and lovers of surf music in general.  Viva Los Straitjackets!
summary: the utterly fantastic and totally unbelievable sound of los straitjackets live. . .
